column1: [1] centrality is a measure of the influence of a node in a network. It assigns relative scores to all nodes in the network based on the concept that connections to high-scoring nodes contribute more to the score of the node in question than equal connections to low-scoring nodes. Google's PageRank and the [2] centrality are variants of it.

In the mathematical area of graph theory, a [1] is a subset of vertices of an undirected graph G such that every two distinct vertices in the [1] are adjacent. Equivalently, a clique of a graph G is an [2] [2] of G that is [3].
A clique of a graph G can also be defined as an induced subgraph of G that is complete. What do (1) induced subgraph and (2) complete mean?
column2:
1 - a subset of the vertices of a graph together with all of the edges that were connecting the vertices in the original graph
2 - every pair of distinct vertices is connected by a unique edge (only valid in 'simple' graphs, as opposed to multigraphs)

column1: Drawings of complete graphs, with their vertices placed on the points of a regular polygon, appeared already in the 13th century, in the work of [1] [1]. Such a drawing is sometimes referred to as a [2] [2].
In graph theory, what are trees and forests?
column2:
In graph theory, a tree is an undirected graph in which any two vertices are connected by exactly one path, or equivalently a connected acyclic undirected graph.

A forest is an undirected graph in which any two vertices are connected by at most one path, or equivalently an acyclic undirected graph, or equivalently a disjoint union of trees.
